video.title: Build a Java Desktop Application - Full Course (Sudoku)
video.description:
Learn to build a Java desktop application in this course. You will learn how to build a Sudoku game using JavaFX.

💻 Code: https://github.com/BracketCove/JavaDesktopSudoku/tree/withoutgradle

🎥 Course from Ryan Kay. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/wiseAss

🔗 Ryan Kay's paid Java Course: https://skl.sh/3fZbjos

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00) Introduction
⌨️ (1:35) Problem Domain Classes (SudokuGame, Coordinates with Hashing, IStorage)
⌨️ (7:41) Constants w/ Enums & static final variables (GameState, Messages, Rows)
⌨️ (9:26) Application Container/Entry Point (SudokuApplication, Main)
⌨️ (12:20) User Interface w/ Java Interfaces (IUserInterfaceContract, EventListener, View)
⌨️ (14:29) User Interface (Custom JavaFX TextField)
⌨️ (17:10) User Interface (UserInterfaceImpl, Managing 81 TextFields Elegantly w/ HashMap) 
⌨️ (45:32) Control Logic (Implementing EventListener similar to MVP/MVC)
⌨️ (50:49) Computation Logic (SudokuUtilities static Helper Methods)
⌨️ (54:00) Computation Logic (GameGenerator Algorithms for generating a new solvable Sudoku Game)
⌨️ (1:06:00) Computation Logic (SudokuSolver Algorithm for Solving a Sudoku Game)
⌨️ (1:12:45) Computation Logic (Entry Point To Back End & Algorithms for Validating a Sudoku Game for Completion)
⌨️ (1:25:57) Build Logic (SudokuBuildLogic for "separating configuration from use" -Martin Fowler)
⌨️ (1:28:44) Persistence/Data Storage (LocalStorageImpl for storing data on the local filesystem)
⌨️ (1:33:49) Acknowledgements & further resources


--



Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Stephen Davies
topLevelComment.text:
This course has good intentions, but honestly how can this be "Good Architecture " and development, if you fail to even run the code once during writing the program??!

There is much good here, but quite a poor implementation and guide for developers, particularly newcomers. Inevitably the application falters on several bugs which were missed as the application was not run till then end.

topLevelComment.author: ahsan yusob
topLevelComment.text:
Hi, I've written the code as I was following through your tutorial and made sure that there is no compile error. I can run the program just fine now, but it is just looping in main method without any sudoke GUI popping out. I have no problem with library import and javafx seems to be included already without needing to add dependencies, so the only thing I did differently is that I didnt download javaFX SDK 11 as you did show in (12:09). Could you help me with this?

I am using java 8 (1.8.0_341) , Gradle 6.9.3, IntelliJ IDEA 2021.2.4 (Community Edition)

replies.author: ahsan yusob
replies.text: oh nevermind. It seems that I created an infinite loop by not adding any "index++" in a while loop where the condition is index<8, so it stucks there. It works now after the fix.

topLevelComment.author: UTR-Gaming
topLevelComment.text: Ok I'm an absolute beginner never programmed anything and things aren't working the same at 2.34 lol, after a bit of messing about assume you are pressing shift+f6 to rename the sudoku folder on the left you type sudoku.publicdomain into the box and click ok and then you have another folder called publicdomain this doesn't work for me any idea's? I'm using intelij 2020.3.2 I can create a new package it's just that I would like to know why this is different also it would be helpful for complete beginners if you started by telling us what keys you are pressing as we can not see sift+f6 is not that intuitive for rename. I represent the sudoku grid as a two dimensional array as you can see here.... um ok, You'll see that I forgot to write int...... did you? where? well as an absolute beginner I stopped the video at this point because telling me you missed something that is obvious and that you will add back in later isn't obvious until you know it. I'm sure this is a fine tutorial for someone that already knows the basics of java but for an absolute beginner your making assumptions on your level of knowledge not mine I'll go read some books I think and maybe comeback to this later should I really get the urge to write a sudoku.

topLevelComment.author: Kent Collins
topLevelComment.text: Very ambitious.  Enjoyed watching and building along.  You may want to double-check the loop conditions for the nested loops in SudokuSolver.isSolveable.  I believe the outer loop is intended to increment the coordinate index of locations that are empty while the inner loop is counting from 1-9.  Thanks for such a wide overview of so many interacting elements with JavaFX and for your favor-an-interface perspective.

topLevelComment.author: Liam Cahill
topLevelComment.text:
It's a bit hard to follow because the pace is so fast. People appreciate it when the instructor does the exercises in real-time and is able to comment live, too, as opposed to doing a voice over after-the-fact. 

That being said, I am glad to have found this tutorial, and I was able to learn some things from it.

replies.author: Aaron

replies.author: Ryan Michael Kay
replies.text:
You are probably thinking of the setX() method from the Rectangle Class in JavaFX. I use the Rectangle class to create lines (among other things), and the setX()/setY() methods will set the X, Y Coordinates of the line relative to the application window.
Visit the Open JFX documentation to see what their methods and classes do. I would post the link but it will probably be grabbed up by a spam filter.

replies.author: Ryan Michael Kay
replies.text:
I go over every concept in my course, Working Class Java. This free tutorial is a compliment to that course, and I explain every topic from absolute basic Java to advanced architecture and OOP principles. I have links to the course in the pinned comment, and FreeCodeCamp has also kindly posted them to the description of this video.
For my IDE, I use Intellij IDEA with Darcula theme enabled.

topLevelComment.author: Moumita Ghosh
topLevelComment.text: What IDE is usual for Java?

replies.author: Moumita Ghosh
replies.text: @wiseAss thnq

replies.author: Ryan Michael Kay
replies.text:
If you plan to be involved in Android Development exclusively, then pick Android Studio. Otherwise, there are three other main options.
- Intellij IDEA: This is what Android Studio is based on. I use this in the tutorial here, and I highly recommend it.
- Eclipse: Eclipse is a very solid open source community tool. It was my first Java IDE back in 2013, and it is pretty good for anything OTHER THAN ANDROID. DO NOT USE IT FOR ANDROID. I have used it for both Java EE (Web Apps) and Desktop though.
- Netbeans: Yeah.... not a fan but some people love it.

replies.author: Ryan Michael Kay
replies.text:
If you plan to be involved in Android Development exclusively, then pick Android Studio. Otherwise, there are three other main options.
- Intellij IDEA: This is what Android Studio is based on. I use this in the tutorial here, and I highly recommend it.
- Eclipse: Eclipse is a very solid open source community tool. It was my first Java IDE back in 2013, and it is pretty good for anything OTHER THAN ANDROID. DO NOT USE IT FOR ANDROID. I have used it for both Java EE (Web Apps) and Desktop though.
- Netbeans: Yeah.... not a fan but some people love it.
